sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; is a status icon (&aka; tray icon) that informs you if you have new mail.
It works with system trays implementing the freedesktop.org System Tray Specification, such as the GNOME Panel Notification Area, the Xfce Notification Area and the KDE System Tray.

listitem.para: multiple mailbox support
&mbox;, &mh;, &maildir;, &pop3;, &imap;, &gmail;, Evolution and &sylpheed; support
&sasl; authentication support
APOP authentication support
&ssl;/&tls; support
automatic detection of mailbox format
immediate notification (the status icon is updated immediately or within seconds after a mailbox changes)
a mail summary
HIG 2.0 compliance

sect2.title: When You Start &app;
sect2.para: When you start &app;, it stays in the background and monitors the status of your mailboxes.
When new mail arrives, an icon similar to the following one is displayed in the notification area (&aka; system tray):

listitem.para: the Mail Notification > New Mail GNOME sound event is emitted (you can configure the sound to be played from the GNOME sound preferences)
if a command to be executed when new mail arrives is set in the Commands properties, that command is executed
if the Enable mail summary popup setting is enabled, an overview of new and unread messages is displayed

sect2.para: If an error is detected, the icon blinks (unless the Blink on errors setting is disabled).
Leaving your mouse over the icon will reveal more details about the status of your mailboxes. Double-clicking on the icon will perform the action specified in the Double-click Action setting.

sect1.para: The main window displays the list of new and unread messages, sorted by sent date in descending order.
The main window can also be used to invoke &app; features when the mail icon is hidden.

sect1.title: Mailbox Properties
sect1.para: The Mailbox Properties dialog is displayed when you add a new mailbox or when you edit an existing one. It contains the following global settings:

listitem.para: This is the type of the mailbox. If you select autodetect, the type will be autodetected using the mailbox &uri; and/or contents.

You can choose to assign a custom name to the mailbox. The mailbox name has informative purposes only, and is displayed in various parts of &app;. To reset to the default name, click on the Use Default button.

note.para: The mailbox name will be modified automatically as you set some of the other options. To avoid losing your choice, only fill in the mailbox name after setting the other options.

sect1.para: The rest of the window depends on the selected mailbox type:

listitem.para:
This is the &uri; of the mailbox.
&app; abstracts file operations by using &gnomevfs;. All the schemes (http, ftp, sftp, ...) supported by &gnomevfs; are therefore supported by &app;.

varlistentry.term: When POP3 or IMAP is selected:

listitem.para:
This is the hostname or IP address of the &pop3; or &imap; server.
Symbolic names as well as IPv4 and IPv6 addresses are supported.
This is your username on the &pop3; or &imap; server. The username will be stored to disk unless it is left blank (in such case, a credentials prompt will appear when needed).
This is your password on the &pop3; or &imap; server. The password will be stored to disk unless it is left blank (in such case, a credentials prompt will appear when needed).

warning.title: Security
warning.para: To avoid sending your password over the network in clear text, you must either use a SSL/TLS connection or select a secure authentication mechanism. See below for more details.

listitem.para: This is the type of connection to use and the port number to connect to.
SSL/TLS on separate port refers to the most widespread method for establishing a &ssl;/&tls; connection: using a separate port.

note.para: The security considerations listed below do not apply if you select SSL/TLS (either in-band or on separate port).

listitem.para: This is the authentication mechanism to use. If you select autodetect, all the authentication mechanisms supported by the &pop3; or &imap; server will be tried, in descending order of security. Otherwise, the selected mechanism (and only the selected mechanism) will be used.

warning.title: Security
warning.para: If autodetect is selected and secure authentication fails, your credentials may be sent over the network in clear text (unless you use a &ssl;/&tls; connection).
If this is a concern, select the appropriate secure authentication mechanism from the drop-down list.

listitem.para: This is the &imap; mailbox to use.
The IDLE extension (as defined by RFC 2177) allows &app; to stay connected to the server and provide immediate notification of changes.

If autodetect is selected, &app; will use the IDLE extension if the server supports it, unless the server software is known to have a broken IDLE implementation (currently, the only such software known to &app; is the University of Washington imapd). This is the recommended choice.

If always is selected, &app; will use the IDLE extension if the server supports it, regardless of the server software. Use this option if you want to force &app; to use the IDLE extension, even if it has detected a bogus implementation.
This is your username on &gmail;. The username will be stored to disk unless it is left blank (in such case, a credentials prompt will appear when needed).
This is your password on &gmail;. The password will be stored to disk unless it is left blank (in such case, a credentials prompt will appear when needed).
This is the Evolution folder to monitor for changes.

note.para: For the folder selector to be available and for monitoring an Evolution mailbox, Evolution must be running and the Evolution Mail Notification plugin must be loaded.

sect1.title: Troubleshooting
sect1.para: If &app; does not work as expected, remember that you can obtain more details by leaving your mouse over its icon.

Additionally, a very efficient way to identify and solve problems is to run &app; using the --enable-info option and examine the output.
Security
The output of --enable-info may contain sensitive information such as passwords and session transcripts.

sect2.title: Immediate Notification
sect2.para: Immediate notification is the ability to detect changes to a mailbox without needing to check it periodically. It allows the status icon to be updated immediately (or within seconds) after a mailbox changes.
Requirements for immediate notification to be enabled:

listitem.para: &gnomevfs; must be compiled with FAM support, and FAM must be configured properly.
Refer to the fam1 manual page for more details.
The &imap; server must support the IDLE extension, as defined by RFC 2177.
There is no requirement. Immediate notification is always enabled.
Immediate notification is not supported by these mailbox types.

note.para: If immediate notification cannot be enabled for a mailbox (either because that type of mailbox does not support it or because the requirements are not met), the mailbox will be checked periodically according to the Delay between mail checks setting.

sect2.title: POP3 Implementation
sect2.para: The &app; &pop3; implementation strictly conforms to RFC 1939, RFC 2449, RFC 1734, RFC 2595 and RFC 2384.
